quote: I start off with kind of a blank slate. What I like to do is load up illustrations I did by hand into Midjourney, and a lot of times I combine those images to see what advances me.
From there, I take what I can use for something else I want to do, which creates a catalog of things I can draw from.
I can either take something from Photoshop and combine numerous elements to create a successful piece, or sometimes I like to use it just as a clear reference.
These days, there are certain competitions or projects that come my way where I'm instructed not to use AI. Even though I still use it for inspiration and reference, I will not use it directly.
Apparently, any and all. But what can you do?
I think of the movie "Her." It got rid of all my junk mail and how AI would know what I want to see or what I would like, while at the same time challenging me to try different and new things.

I think of right now Spotify and how the algorithm so many times suggests things that I don't like, which is shocking to me because they're supposed to monitor my likes and tastes. I feel like sometimes that's not particularly successful, and I have to work too hard to find the things I like.
I guess help me with time management, which is something we all struggle with, I think.
Just manage my time better and know how I spend my time.
Our Google Calendar, something like that.
Straight to the point, without emotion, which I liked. It was very seamless.
I do feel like an AI bot is listening rather than a human interpreting.
